												After purchase you can play this as a MOD within the Arma 2 AND Arma 3 games to keep the multiplayer functionality and provide many many visual and gameplay improvements. Go to the official Bohemia Interactive forums and check the threads "Iron Front as mod in Arma 2: Combined Operations" and "Iron Front as mod in Arma 3". This is a very lovely tribute based on the Arma 2 engine. You will enjoy all the richness of features - open world scenario with an editor for unlimited possibilities. Playing the mission "Normandy crossing" gave me that immersion, only the Arma series can provide. Laying there with my team at dawn, covering in the grass and behind bushes. Looking at the wonderful colors of the sky, listening to the beautiful soft wind breeze around our helmets and for a short time I remember how it was playing in the wilderness as a young kid. But then reality forces me to focus ont the gravel road to the west. My team hears it - I hear it. There it is. The terrifying whistling and twittering of German tank tracks coming closer and closer. They are less than 200 meters away, but we still have no visual contact. Oh god, save our souls. I order my team to hold fire. Then we have visual contact to a German halftrack fully manned with troops. I know, that the only possibilitiy to survive, is to take out the gunner first, because he can erase our whole team with one single blast. They come to a halt, just 50 meters away from us. This is our chance! Quickly I focus on the gunner and order my members 2 to 5 to attack him, the rest of my team will handle the two guards on foot to the left and right, Open fire! Lucky us, the gunner and guards drop immediately, but the whole squad now disembarks the halftrack, running for cover. A fierce battle ends as we empty our last mags into the one Kraut calling for reinforcements. We check the dead Germans for ammo, gear and weapons and say goodbye to our fallen comrades. Suddenly we are shocked to death. There it is again. The whistling of death....

												7.8/10+Realistic+Massive Maps+Extremely Customizable+Intense Combat-Clunky Controls-Dumb AI-Graphical Inconsistancies  I think this game gets too bad of a reputation from those who pick it up for the first time. Let me preface this with a couple of things: Yes, it does have bugs, Yes it does have graphical inconsistancies (Low res textures, shoddy character modeling, etc), Yes, it does have a complicated control scheme, and yes the AI isn't exactly top notch. With all of this in mind I still would recommend this game; not to players who are familiar with fast paced shooters like Team Fortress, Call of Duty, Battlefield, or anything like that, but to those who are looking for a realistic, stategical, satisfying tactical experience. Let me address the first problem many players complain about: The control scheme. To be honest, I don't get what the big deal is. I mean if we are talking bare-bones-pick-up-and-play-with-no-prior-knowledge-of-the-controls gameplay, you WILL find that it is a bit clunky, but if you stop and go to the settings, you can customize the control scheme virtually to any way you want. There are a lot of actions that you will not use, so simply map those away from the main controls. You have the ability to map buttons to the same command, making them toggleable. So realistically, just map the controls to the way you are used to them and everything will be fine.This game offers an assortment of different units, guns, and vehicles to play with. All are historically accurate and accuratly designed. The sound captuing is a little iffy, as most weapons sound the same. This game drops you in the shoes of either a German soldier, or a Russian soldier (or an American if you buy the DLC). The maps the missions take place in are rather huge, and the gameplay time from mission to mission can vary from 10 minutes, to 2 hours, depending on how you play. The  battles feel very realistic. This game can prove to be very difficult to those who like to run out into the open and play super hero. The good/ bad thing about that, is that you will have to start from the last checkpoint if you die, so this game forces you to move slowly and assess the situation.You are in control of your AI team mates most of the time. This is the only instance where the controls, for me, got clunky. To select a unit, you will push the F1-F12 buttons, and to issue a command, you will find it by pushing the 1-0 keys. In the middle of a firefight, this can become tedious, and will often result in you either picking the wrong command, or scrolling through the number keys to find the command. It also doesn't help that the AI react slowly, so if you tell them to hit the dirt, or give suppressive fire, they will think about it for about ten seconds before acting, but this is only when there are many units on the field at once.While I do not have the patience to describe every aspect of the game, I can tell you that this game has flaws, but if you are looking for a good, strategic game, this is the one to buy. It needs work, and I hope they make a second one with fewer bugs.

They optimized their game very well and are clearly lovers of the history here. The hardware, all of it, is pain-stakingly detailed and accurate. The powerful ArmA 2 mission editor is there, the AI is improved, it's all an improvement on ArmA 2. For $29.99? Yeah, this is all worth it. An obscure theatre in WWII is welcome and the developers have already released DLC for it. Two campaigns covering the Soviet and Wehrmahct forces in both English and their native languages. The developers are history buffs and did the subject matter due justice without showing any overt bias to any faction. If you love sims, if you love more realism in you games, this is one you honestly should get. It's clearly made BY history buffs FOR history buffs.

Posted: October 27, 2013
												Iron Front : Liberation 1944 is a pretty nice looking total conversion for the ARMA 2 engine. The majority of the unit graphics are debatably nicer than that of some vanilla ARMA 2 units. Likewise, most of the units available in Iron Front : Liberation 1944 look authentic and there is a fair amount of equipment from late in the war. Sadly, these are the only real compliments that come to mind when I think of this "game."So what's the real problem here? Well, first off: The AI is pretty anemic. A hallmark n00b gripe with ARMA is that of the omnipotent and almighty - "Uber Cheaty" - AI (with eyes in the back of their collective head.) Sadly, this isn't the case for the AI in Iron Front : Liberation 1944... In fact a major complaint about this "game" is that the AI is dumber than a box of rocks and as a long time (since 2001) ARMA player, I'd have to disagree... Despite the fact that Iron Front : Liberation 1944 is built on the ARMA II engine and despite the largely identical command menus, I feel as though something was lost during the total conversion... So much so that the AI in Iron Front : Liberation 1944 appears to be dumber than a dump truck load of boulders.As an example: I watched two opposing tank platoons pass right by one another without firing a shot. Being the commander of a lead tank, it was my experience that the command menu in Iron Front : Liberation 1944 is almost completely useless. Due largely to the inept, incompetent and insubordinate nature of the AI in this "game."After watching the enemy tank column pass by my platoon at point blank range, I tried giving each of my tank gunners their own specific targets. No results... Ok, well how about each of you try opening fire? No? Not interested? Ok... Maybe we can all just stand around, hold hands and discuss how we feel? Would you like to do that? Guess not...Don't worry though, the AI's lack of sighting, reporting and automatic engagement skills isn't likely to result in any casualties... Realistically, I don't think that any of the AI driven units in the "game" actually pose a threat to the player. However, I do think that boredom is a serious threat to anyone who plays Iron Front : Liberation 1944. Which brings me to my final point, is this a "game" or a "paid total conversion mod?" As a standalone game, the AI is pretty lacking, there is no default CTI mode and the majority of the maps are pretty small... Even if you consider this as a paid total conversion mod of ARMA II - it lacks the depth of content you're likely to find in some unpaid addons, mods / total conversion for the various versions of ARMA...Which ever way you approach this - I think that if you really want an ARMAesque, WWII experience, you would be better off finding your own collection of WWII addon units and maps for ARMA I, II or III...---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Is Iron Front : Liberation 1944 a decent, large scale land / air WWII sim?Absolutely! If you could consistently get enough players together for huge multiplayer battles it would probably be a pretty fun game.Is Iron Front : Liberation 1944 a complete ARMA II experience set in WWII?Nope... Too much functionality and challenge was left behind... The reason the ARMA series has been so successful has been its community, both in terms of players and content makers... Which is something that Iron Front : Liberation 1944 currently lacks.Unless you've got money to burn - this game is a pass.

												Iron Front is a simulator, not counter strike and not Call of Duty. It's a WW2 simulator with the focus on infantry tactics. You can use tanks, vehicles and planes, but they're not 1:1 simulated. Good, but not prefect.The power of Iron Front comes from the close to real approach of the correct presentation of all uniforms, ranks, languages (with dialects) and human dialogs.The game shows you, during the campaign, that war is no place for heroes and that you're as good as dead if you think that you're the best fps gamer in the world, because you know how to play candy strike ehm..sorry..counter strike.If you like hard core gameplay, stick to this. Many features, many options, but brutal as hell. If you want to brag about you kills and upgrades, stay away. There're none in this game. And it does matter if you kill some one to make sure he's alone. You don't want to fight a squad of angry soldiers on your own.NOTE: You do need a rather high-end game rig for this game, otherwise it won't run smooth enough. But, if you got that.. Nothing stands in your way to enjoy this Red Orchestra killer. Ofcourse, all a matter of taste, but this is my nr. 1 favorite World War 2 Co-Op Simulation.

Meanwhile I enjoyed the really good german voice over that seems pretty authentic (no irony this time, they did a good job on that).Arrived at the shooting range for basic training. After listening to some more propaganda about german war material I received a rifle and suddenly I saw why they fu**ed up the camera controls so badly. Simply because using the mouse does not rotate or manipulate the camera itself as you would suggest, but it lets you drag the imaginary aim point of the rifle across the screen, which is then beeing followed by the first person camera. I don't know why they tried to revolutionize a simple mechanic that has worked perfectly fine in thousands of other games before, but they failed.So already lacking of motivation I tried to convince myself that maybe they where trying to enhance realism, and that's why...Two minutes later I perfectly hit some targets with an unmounted mg42 from a standing position and over a distance of a few hundred meters.I quit the "game" and decided to write this review, which was basically more fun than playing Iron Front itself!

												 Ursprünglich eine Mod für Arma 2 gewesen, aber aufgrund der Beliebtheit jetzt als eigenständiges Spiel erhältlich. Strategische, anspruchsvolle und äußerst spannende Gefechte an der Ostfront, wahlweise auf russischer oder deutscher Seite. Realismus pur dank dem Arma 2- Grundgerüst. Am besten für Kenner der Arma- oder Operation: Flashpoint- Reihe. Die einzelnen Missionen können sehr langwierig sein und locker 2 - 3 Stunden dauern. Man muss taktisch und im Team vorgehen, Einzelgänger haben keine Chance! Man beginnt als Schütze, muss aber bald seinen ersten Infanteriezug befehligen, und das ist bitter nötig um die Missionen zu erfüllen. Später im Spiel gesellen sich ganze Panzerzüge dazu. Der Spieler kann (und muss) sämtliche Fahr- und Flugzeuge selbst steuern, allerdings sind bei Panzern mehrere Soldaten nötig, da jede Position im Panzer besetzt sein muss, damit er am besten funktioniert. Wer sich einmal in das komplexe Befehlssystem reingefuchst hat, wird mit spannenden und nervenaufreibenden Gefechten in  wunderschöner Grafik belohnt. So gut wurde die Ostfront in noch keinem Shooter umgesetzt! Störend sind höchstens die etwas mangelhafte Wegfindung der KI-Kameraden und gelegentliche amerikanische Sprachsamples (Kein deutscher Landser hätte damals "Oh♥♥♥♥♥♥" oder "♥♥♥♥!" gerufen), die noch ein Überbleibsel aus dem "Hauptspiel" Arma 2 sind.

Am besten für Kenner der Arma- oder Operation: Flashpoint- Reihe. Die einzelnen Missionen können sehr langwierig sein und locker 2 - 3 Stunden dauern. Man muss taktisch und im Team vorgehen, Einzelgänger haben keine Chance! Man beginnt als Schütze, muss aber bald seinen ersten Infanteriezug befehligen, und das ist bitter nötig um die Missionen zu erfüllen. Später im Spiel gesellen sich ganze Panzerzüge dazu. Der Spieler kann (und muss) sämtliche Fahr- und Flugzeuge selbst steuern, allerdings sind bei Panzern mehrere Soldaten nötig, da jede Position im Panzer besetzt sein muss, damit er am besten funktioniert. Wer sich einmal in das komplexe Befehlssystem reingefuchst hat, wird mit spannenden und nervenaufreibenden Gefechten in  wunderschöner Grafik belohnt. So gut wurde die Ostfront in noch keinem Shooter umgesetzt! Störend sind höchstens die etwas mangelhafte Wegfindung der KI-Kameraden und gelegentliche amerikanische Sprachsamples (Kein deutscher Landser hätte damals "Oh♥♥♥♥♥♥" oder "♥♥♥♥!" gerufen), die noch ein Überbleibsel aus dem "Hauptspiel" Arma 2 sind.
